contentrichtext.text: {{Other uses|Dusk (disambiguation)}} {{distinguish|sunset}} [[Image:Twilight subcategories.svg|thumb|right|300px|Civil, nautical, and astronomical twilight. Dusk is the end of evening [[twilight]]<ref name="Low precision formulae">{{cite journal|bibcode=1979ApJS...41..391V|last=Van Flandern|first=T.|coauthors=K. Pulkkinen|title=Low precision formulae for planetary positions|journal=Astrophysical Journal, Supplement Series |volume=31|issue=3|year=1980|doi = 10.1086/190623 }}</ref>]] '''Dusk''' is the darkest stage of [[twilight]] in the [[evening]]. During early to intermediate stages of twilight, there may be enough light in the sky under clear-sky conditions to read outdoors without artificial illumination. '''Civil dusk''' occurs when the earth rotates to a point at which the center of the [[sun]] is at 6° below the local horizon. This marks the end of the evening [[twilight#Civil twilight|civil twilight]], the point where artificial illumination is required to read outside.<ref name="USNOTwilightDefs"> [[U.S. Naval Observatory]] [http://www.usno.navy.mil/USNO/astronomical-applications/astronomical-information-center/rise-set-twi-defs Rise, Set, and Twilight Definitions].</ref> Twilight comes after ''[[sunset]]'', which is the point at which the earth has rotated just enough that the sun is no longer visible on the local horizon (under clear conditions). __TOC__ == Technical definitions == [[File:Silhouette of a tree at dusk..JPG|thumb|Silhouette of a tree at dusk]] There are also more technical definitions of dusk, including the following: ; Civil dusk : The time at which the sun is 6 degrees below the horizon in the evening. At this time objects are distinguishable and some stars and planets are visible to the naked eye. ; Nautical dusk : Is when the sun is 12 degrees below the horizon in the evening. At this time, objects are no longer distinguishable, and the horizon is no longer visible to the naked eye. ; Astronomical dusk : The time at which the sun is 18 degrees below the horizon in the evening. At this time the sun no longer illuminates the sky, and thus no longer interferes with astronomical observations. [[File:Seattle 3.jpg|thumb|left|600px|[[Seattle]], [[Washington (state)|Washington]] at dusk]] {{-}} <gallery> Image:PortoCovo February 2008-4.jpg|Dusk in [[Porto Covo]], west coast of Portugal Image:Dusk-A330.JPG|Dusk, seen from a plane on cruise Image:IbirapueraDusk.jpg|[[São Paulo]] at dusk, view from [[Ibirapuera Park]] Image:Hell on Earth.jpg|Dusk in [[Joshua Tree, California]], USA </gallery> == See also == * [[Dawn]] * [[Sunrise]] * [[Sunset]] * [[Twilight]] == References == {{Reflist}} {{Parts of a day}} [[Category:Earth phenomena]] [[Category:Parts of a day]] [[Category:Night]] [[bjn:Sanja]] [[nl:Schemering]] [[ms:Senja]] [[ru:Сумерки]] [[sv:Skymning]]
